description: From Middle English blome, from Old Norse bl√≥m, from Proto-Germanic *bl≈çm√¥ (‚Äúflower‚Äù). Doublet of bloom (‚Äúspongy mass of metal‚Äù); see there for more.

entries.meaning: A blossom; the flower of a plant; an expanded bud.
examples: the rich blooms and enamelled vegetation of the tropics

entries.meaning: (collective) Flowers.
(uncountable) The opening of flowers in general; the state of blossoming or of having the flowers open.
examples: The cherry trees are in bloom.

entries.meaning: (figuratively) A state or time of beauty, freshness, and vigor; an opening to higher perfection, analogous to that of buds into blossoms.
Rosy colour; the flush or glow on a person's cheek.
The delicate, powdery coating upon certain growing or newly-gathered fruits or leaves, as on grapes, plums, etc.
examples: The bloom on blueberries is the dusty powder that protects them from the Sun; it does not rinse off.

entries.meaning: Anything giving an appearance of attractive freshness.
An algal bloom.
The clouded appearance which varnish sometimes takes upon the surface of a picture.
A yellowish deposit or powdery coating which appears on well-tanned leather.
(mineralogy) A bright-hued variety of some minerals.
(cooking) A white area of cocoa butter that forms on the surface of chocolate when warmed and cooled.
(television) An undesirable halo effect that may occur when a very bright region is displayed next to a very dark region of the screen.
(video games) The increase in bullet spread over time as a gun's trigger is kept held.

verbs.description: bloom (third-person singular simple present blooms, present participle blooming, simple past and past participle bloomed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cause to blossom; to make flourish.
(transitive) To bestow a bloom upon; to make blooming or radiant.
(intransitive) Of a plant, to produce blooms; to open its blooms.
(intransitive, figuratively) Of a person, business, etc, to flourish; to be in a state of healthful, growing youth and vigour; to show beauty and freshness.
examples: A better country blooms to view, / Beneath a brighter sky.

entries.meaning: (cooking) To bring out the flavor of a spice by cooking it in oil.
(intransitive, cooking, of chocolate) To develop a layer of bloom (white, spotty areas of cocoa butter) due to repeated warming and cooling.

description: From Middle English blome, from Old English bl≈çma (‚Äúflower; lump of metal‚Äù), from Proto-Germanic *bl≈çm√¥ (‚Äúflower‚Äù). Cognate with West Frisian blom, Dutch bloem, German Blume, Icelandic bl√≥m, Danish blomme, Gothic êå±êåªêçâêåºêå∞ (bl≈çma). Related to blow, blade, blead; also related to flower, foil, and belladonna.

entries.meaning: The spongy mass of metal formed in a furnace by the smelting process.
examples: These metallic bodies gradually increasing in volume finally conglomerate into a larger mass, the bloom, which is extracted from the furnace with tongs.
